39423101.review:
The Last Door est un jeu de niche. Publié en 2013 suite à son Kickstarter réussi par The Game Kitchen dont c'est le premier jeu. On a affaire à un Point&Click avec des graphismes en Ultra Low-Res, pourtant le jeu arrive à avoir un style graphique et à se former un univers par la formation des environnements, l'ambiance qui s'en dégage et la répétiton de thèmes et d'elements de décors particulier. Le scénario est le jeu en général est grandement inspiré par le travail du Maitre de Providence et de son Mythe. Le jeu est en deux saisons de 4 chapitres. Le premier chapitre de la saison est disponible gratuitement sur le site du jeu. Ici je ne "spoilerai" (et encore très peu) seulement l'intro du premier chapitre.

Le jeu commence sur une scène d'une réussite absolu, où nous choisissons les actions d'un personnage parmis, un seul et unique choix. Par ce procédé scénaristique liant le game design et le scénario le jeu montre la détresse du personnage et le fait qu'il n'a justement aucun autre choix. Ce qui est aussi le cas du joueur. Ainsi le jeu parvient habilement à lié le joueur au personnage.

Voilà, j'ai démontré selon moi le génie de The Last Door. Le jeu a beau être un jeu d'horreur il n'a aucun screamer juste une ambiance terrifiante et oppresante comme Lovecraft savait si bien faire. Le premier chapitre est une réussite incontésté, le second a quelques defaults (des énigmes moins explicites) mais le troisième puis le quatrièles chapitres sont très bon aussi.

En conclusion si vous aimez Lovecraft, les Points&Click et que la Low-Res ne vous dérange pas, achetez ce chez-d'oeuvre...

Ou du moins essayez la démo ^^

通过鼠标点点点走动、和物品互动，触发剧情。

一个学生时代的诅咒渐渐显露其威力，主角踏上了寻找真相之路。

游戏通过一个充满神秘主义的主线故事将四章节不同地点的事件调查活动串联起来。学生时代的联盟、诅咒、凶杀、宗教仪式、灵异事件，主角等人不断追随线索前行，想要找出幕后真相。
个人认为游戏的主要优点，在于其营造的神秘气氛。至于它到底讲了个什么故事，玩完了也难以描述出个大概。。。就是靠一股气吊着玩家，不断继续点击下去。。。

39388162.review:
A splendid little horror game reminiscent of the occult works of the 19th Century.  The gameplay is interesting enough to keep you going, the puzzles are fairly straightforward and there is not too much pixel-hunting, but the game really shines in its atmosphere.  The graphics add to the other-wordly charm, and the use of colour and lighting in particular gives everything a sinister hue.  The soundtrack really stands out and is suitably ominious.  

As someone who both loves horror and is extremely picky about it, this does horror correctly, delving into the dark space between worlds, grasping at the unknowable in all its majestic and malevolent incomprehensibility, and glimpsing only shards of the terrible.  Avoiding spoilers, the end has a nice moment of the inevitablity of curiosity (which not so much 'kills the cat' as 'exposes the human to nightmarish truths').  Not quite Lovecraftian, but certainly if you like the works of Arthur Machen, Clark Ashton Smith and some of Poe's more supernatural works, worth a look.

39224825.review:
Pixels the size of a finger? Yup! Does it look good? Oh yes. A baroque pearl of gaming. A truly unique experience. Its scary, its disturbing, but not too much, just enough, everything about this game is just right. It feels like watching an old horror movie, its not really that horrible, but it feels haunted. It's got its inspirations right, Its lovecraftian whithout being Lovecraft, its atari without being atari, its Hammer without being a Hammer film. 
The extremely pixelated graphics are like a tour de force, it shows that games can be immersive and atmospheric even if they aren't realistic: all you need is coherence, may love be damned, even if there's so much love involved. 
This game feels like a love affair, there should be so much wrong with it, but it feels right. As a long time adventure fan I can only criticize this: its too easy. The puzzles are a bit obvious, even when they are trying to be tricky. Being this a horror game it could have been more inventive with puzzles, but it went a different road, to be inventive with horror.
And it went big on that road. The story is magnificent, The execution, flawless. It disturbs, mesmerizes and plays with feelings and perception. Seaason 1 is particularly strong in those regards. Season 2 tries to mostly provide answers, and it does that too well, which is a sin. Its not bad, but I wanted more, yet it just makes everything as close and as shut as it can, no room for sequels, and its a damn shame. S1 just shows so much potential, and S2 just closes the drapes.
I understand that indie games are an experiment and the goal of the designers is to go to the major leages, making AAA titles and earning the big bucks... but indies are big risktakers, and risk rewards creativity. Big bucks are conservative, and souls are lost in the process.
Last Door is a tale about lost souls. This game is haunted by so many... What was, what could have been, what is... Its great, but what haunts me the most is what it could've been, and never will be.
We were shown the door, and it was the last.

39223730.review:
The Last Door - Season One is an episodic, point-and-click game with a story full of mystery, horror, and intrigue.  There were just so many little details in the game that bolstered the story that extra little bit that really made this game stick out for me.  The soundtrack for one is absolutely superb and made for a great atmosphere.  And while you'd think the pixelated art-style would hurt the game, as horror of any media requires good imagery, the art-style actually sold out and I believe in some places even made things scarier!  I'd especially like to mention the puzzles in this game, as they were surely lovingly made.  They were just so unique in design and I believe quite possible some of the best puzzles I've ever played in a game like this, especially the last puzzle near the end of the game!   And did I mention there are little Easter Eggs in the game?

Overall, The Last Door envokes a similar emotion I get from reading pieces from the masters of mystery and horror.  It's Sir Arthur Conan Doyle paired up with Edgar Allen Poe and H.P. Lovecraft: absurd, disturbing, horrifying, and wonderful.  It's a game I won't soon forget, and this is just the first season!

Historia, oparta głównie na motywach okultystycznych, jest ciekawa i popycha gracza do przodu nie pozwaląjąc się nudzić. Esta aventura gráfica demuestra que no hace falta unos gráficos de última generación para ser un juego sobresaliente y además demuestra que en España puede hacerse videojuegos digno de elogios, porque es lo único que saldrá de servidora de este pequeño pero a la vez gran título.

Se nos presenta una historia llena de intriga (no quiero dar detalle alguno, cuanto menos sepais de la trama mejor) en cuatro capítulos que poco a poco va cogiendo más forma de una manera retorcida que nos mantendrá en tensión con más de un susto sin contar con el magnifico trabajo respecto al sonido, con ruidos de fondo que nos pondrán en alerta a la mínima y una banda sonora que acompaña perfectamente a este tipo de aventura.

La durabilidad de The last door no es especialmente alta aunque tambien dependerá de la habilidad del jugador a la hora de resolver los obstáculos que se nos presenta, que en algunos casos puede ser una dificultad algo alta (especialmente para aquellos que no estén acostumbrados a este género).

Cabe decir que el final te deja con ganas de mucho más, pero por suerte ya podemos adquirir la segunda parte por lo que se les puede perdonar que nos dejen con la miel en los labios.

¿Recomiendo The Last Door?

Si eres fan de las aventuras gráficas, te gusta el misterior y/o te apasiona las novelas de Lovecraft o Edgar Allan Poe no sé a que esperas para disfrutar de este videojuego, porque te garantizo que no te dejará indiferente.

38459816.review:
[h1][b]Geschichte[/b][/h1]
Wir spiele Jeremiah Devitt. Er erhält von seinem Freund Anthony eine Bitte ihm zu helfen und als wir bei Ihm ankommen Ahnen wir noch nicht in was wir da hinein geraten sind. Auch Ahnen wir noch nicht das die Vergangenheit uns langsam einholt. Es gilt die Mysterien des Vorfalles zu entschlüsseln und auch was wir selber damit zu tun haben.

[h1][b]Grafik[/b][/h1]
Die Grafik ist schön für ein 2D Pixel Spiel. Es wurde hier auch viel auf kleine Details geachtet. Effekte wie Licht und Wetter werden auch hervorragend dargestellt.

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]
Es ist ein typisches Point & Klick spiel und wir brauchen wirklich nicht mehr als unsere Maus. Auch gibt es nicht viel Möglichkeiten was wir tun können: Gehen/Suchen/Nehmen und die Gegenstände benutzen. [h1][b]Wiederspielwert[/b][/h1]
Da wir auch das ein oder andere Geheimnis lüften können und wir hier auch ein paar Erfolge haben, sowie eine wirklich gute Geschichte voller Spannung. Kann man das Spiel gut 2 oder 3 mal spielen.

[h1][b]Fazit[/b][/h1]
Eine packende Geschichte voller Spannung und Schreckmomente. 
Einfach gehalten aber trotzdem macht es viel Spaß dieses Spiel zu spielen und bin auf die 2. Season gespannt.

После прохождения данной игры у меня осталось куча эмоций, которые не способны передать 99% игр.
Первое и самое интересное, во времена  Dota 2, CS:GO, PUBG мы порой не замечаем таких шедевров игровой индустрии как The Last Door. Скажу сразу, этот продукт далеко не для всех. 

Первое с чем сталкивается игрок - графика, которая выполнена в стиле Pixel Art и такой стиль подоходит немногим играм, но, я хочу заметить, что именно для этой игры он ложится просто идеально. Художники проделали большую работу и это видно невооруженным глазом. Ваше воображение само дорисовывает картинку за вас придавая игре больший шарм, дополняя её новыми красками и таинственностью. Ведь, когда вы купите современную хорошую игру, то в ней вашему мозгу нужно лишь любоваться картинкой, ничего не нужно додумывать. Это не хорошо и не плохо, каждому своё, но, мне нравится именно додумать, как в книге, когда ты читаешь текст и представляешь себе главных героев, действие и прочее...

Про эту игру можно сказать очень многое и хочется только хвалить. Перед нами мистической хоррор, который относится к жанру "point and click". В первом сезоне(а их всего два) существует 4 эпизода, каждый из которых раскрывает нам тайну и показывает сюжет с разных ракурсов от лица главных героев, которые связаны между собой нелегкой, мистической и страшной судьбой. 

Музыкальная составляющая - это отдельная тема для разговора. Вся музыка была написана одним композитором Carlos Viola и он сумел очень точно передать всю эту таинственность, мрачность, местами безысходность той атмосферы в которую нас игра погружает с головой. Касательно звуков: все скрипит, где-то кто-то смеется, плачет, дует ветер, идет дождь всё живёт своей жизнью и это восхитительно.

Из минусов можно отметить лишь отсутствие русского языка, но, всегда можно найти русификатор. Лично я прошёл её на анлийском и ничуть не жалею, это даже придало большей атмосферы. Весь первый сезон можно пройти за часов 6-10 особо не спеша и наслаждаясь каждым кусочком этого вкусного торта).

Если попытаться рискнуть и оценить этот шедевр, то, в моём понимании оценки следующие:

Музыка 10/10
Сюжет 9.5/10
Графика 10/10

36568434.review:
Strutturato in 4 episodi usciti a qualche mese di distanza tramite Kickstarter, The Last Door è un'avventura grafica horror molto ispirata alle opere di Lovecraft e Poe in cui interpretiamo un tale, Devitt, che riceve un'allarmante lettera da un suo vecchio compagno di collegio e decide di andare a vedere cosa succede. Inutile dirlo, sarà solo l'inizio di una discesa nella follia, con Devitt che dovrà fare i conti con quanto accadde in quel collegio molti anni prima e che vide coinvolto anche lui.

La cosa che salta immediatamente all'occhio è la grafica, una pixel art che sembra fatta con Paint (e probabilmente lo è) e che rende minimalissimo tutto quanto, dai tratti somatici dei personaggi agli oggetti. Anche se particolare, però, direi che funziona abbastanza e riesce a rendere bene le varie scene drammatiche o inquietanti, senza risparmiarsi in effetti sanguinolenti.
Dove funziona meno è forse nel cercare di capire COSA ogni manciata di pixel effettivamente sia, ma fortunatamente viene in nostro aiuto una grossa lente di ingrandimento che evidenzia gli oggetti di interesse che altrimenti si potrebbero non notare in quel caos pixelato. 

Come di consueto c'è un inventario in cui si possono esaminare gli oggetti raccolti e combinarli tra loro, e gli enigmi sono tutto sommato riusciti - anche se un paio hanno soluzioni un po' tirate per i capelli e non molto intuitive. 

L'atmosfera inquietante è buona e la storia mantiene vivo l'interesse finendo sempre con un qualche colpo di scena, con ogni episodio che dura sì e no 40 minuti e il terzo che è forse quello più noiosetto e meno riuscito. 
Ad accompagnare il tutto, un'eccellente colonna sonora di pianoforte e violini e ottimi effetti sonori che a volte fanno saltare su dalla sedia. 
Nota di merito anche per la buonissima traduzione italiana che rispetta un certo modo di scrivere degli scrittori a cui il gioco si ispira. 

Alla fine un titolo discreto anche se breve, in 2-3 orette si arriva alla fine (che prosegue poi nella Season 2) quindi valutate se prenderlo a prezzo pieno. La rigiocabilità non è molta, ma volendo si possono rigiocare gli episodi singolarmente alla ricerca dei diversi segreti nascosti in giro - o si può guardare la guida che si fa prima.

36228070.review:
Not a terrible game by any means, just uninspired and not very engaging one.

The extremely low resolution (which isn't even adopted consistently, as some elements of the interface are pixellated differently than the main area while the lighting effects are high-res, leading to some stylistic dissonances) was a very poor choice for this particular game. Since the whole point-and-click mechanism depends on the player's ability to locate particular objects within the environment, rendering these objects as indistinguishable blocky blobs can only lead to tedious and annoying experience. The narrative ambitions of the storyline are also severely curtailed by the limited graphics: all of the "creepy" or "dramatic" moments come off as quaint at best. Pixelation of this magnitude causes a powerful alienation effect which seems out of place in a game attempting to tell a captivating story.

Speaking of story, I'm sorry to say that it consists mostly of tired clichés seemingly pulled together from bad 1980s Call of Cthulhu scenarios. The few interesting and original ideas are left underdeveloped; the characters (including the PC) are paper-thin. Since there is very little to look at, one would expect the writing to be the main driving force behind the narrative; unfortunately, it is merely adequate, with some irritating anachronistic word choices and lines of dialogue reminiscent of school plays.

Gameplay-wise, The Last Door offers no innovation at all and does little to alleviate problems present in the adventure genre since its inception. There is way too much walking around at an unhurried pace and trying random combinations of objects in hope to guess the developers' intentions. None of the puzzles felt particularly clever and some depended on the kind of nonsensical (or at best extremely non-intuitive) object interactions that point-and-click games are notorious for.

While playing through all the four episodes was a mildly entertaining distraction, at times the game made me feel bored and miserable and there wasn't a single aspect of it which in my eyes would make it stand above the average. I'm afraid I can't recommend it with any enthusiasm.

I should also note that the game crashed twice upon entering new locations; fortunately, the auto-save feature worked as expected and no progress was lost.

[h1]An Adventure, a Symphony[/h1]

Overview in short: A mystery/horror adventure that relies less on shock and scare tactics but on smart storytelling.

The Last Door is an adventure game, that is made in the style of classic point and click adventures, the graphic is retro style, very pixelated - yet you can clearly recognize the stuff you need to see. The story of the game is very well written and reminds a bit on old horror-stories. The author and devs have tried to use the atmosphere of the setting to it's fullest, and this is even more underlined by a magnificient Soundtrack that accompanies this game.

You can solve this game in one go, but you are bound to miss out a lot of stuff, either notes or secrets that are hidden somewhere. So you might have to repeat some of the game, only to find the hidden stuff. As I already said in the short, the game relies on heavy storytelling, there are dozens of books, diaries and notes to be found - they all give hints and help to solve the game, and unfolding the story.

The game is fun to play, although if you know the story, the replayability is bound to the time, you play it again, after some years or months a revitalisation of the game might come in handy. But playing it directly after the first time again is a bit too much. There is only a limited replayability, as with many adventure games, but that doesn't do the game any harm.

The game itself is short, you can well beat the game in less time that I played it, around six to seven hours would be the normal time frame, but you would leave a lot of things unrecognized. 

I [b]recommend[/b] this game out of the reasons unconditionally, especially the soundtrack transposes this game into a very immersive and atmospheric experience.

34874516.review:
总之就是个点击式冒险解谜游戏，说得通的剧情和谜题破解方式，毫无逻辑可循的主角行为。嗯，很传统的，和所有90年代同类游戏一样让你解开谜题后完全理解不了主角为什么会做出这种事。

不过反正流程推进了，就不要在意为什么第一次去别人家里会想到剪主人家窗帘之类的事情吧。

虽然在类型标签中明确写着“洛夫克拉夫特式”，但本作的克苏鲁元素实际上只是作为点缀的作用。游戏说蕴含的经典文学元素，远比传统的“洛式恐怖游戏”要丰富得多。整个流程最令人称道的便是对气氛的渲染 —— 独具韵味的台词、出色的节奏配合感染力极强的音效，将玩家一步步带进充满神秘感的故事中。

作为一款游戏来说，TLD的节奏紧凑，故事充满悬念，人物的刻画入木三分。比起在多数克苏鲁故事里头，注定要倒霉而显得无所谓的主角来说，游戏的几位主要人物的身世与遭遇却很容易引起玩家关注。

第一季的四个章节中，玩家随着戴维调查同窗好友的死因，并因此被卷入一场多年前引发的离奇事件。故事的灵感来源自爱伦坡（从没看过）、梅琴（从没听说过）和爱手艺（这个知道了！）等人的文学作品。对于熟读这些原著的玩家来说，在推进流程时应该会获得更好的体验。

但即便是从未接触过这些文学经典（比如我）的人，将其视为一个风格古典、但故事题材又十分新颖的恐怖冒险游戏也能同样得到十分完美的体验。

当一个游戏的人物脸部建模只有五个像素块时，你要如何推论出对方当前的表情样貌？

之前在聊恶灵附身的时候我说过：人的恐惧来源之一便是对于未知事物的不安。许多恐怖游戏都会尝试用各种表现手法，来模糊作品中人物与事件的形象，以达到让玩家自己越猜越害怕的效果。

TLD低像素的画面，刚好为游戏本身添上了一层朦胧的质感。人物的情感变化、场景环境与事态发生时的景象，都需要玩家将配乐、台词与那如同笼罩在迷雾当中的画面相结合。这种通过想象力来填补空白信息的手段，不正是克苏鲁文学最经典的案例吗？

开发商是一个西班牙的小独立工作室，由于经济条件的限制，游戏的推出速度比较缓慢。但是随着被越来越多的玩家了解到，开发组似乎也慢慢摆脱了经费的困境（在每一章结束后还可以看到逐渐增加的支持人数）。

相比较来说，第一章的故事带着一种奇妙的美感，似乎即便是戛然而止也没有丝毫问题。而第二章我个人觉得有种扩宽得太多，让原本透着一层绝望气息的故事变得稍微“俗”了点。希望只是因为故事章节的过渡导致的错觉，期待在后续故事（如果有）中会更加完整吧。

34824375.review:
Un'avventura punta-e-clicca con un'atmosfera lovecraftiana da non perdere!

La storia è molto intrigante ed è il fulcro principale dell'intero gioco. Nei panni di Devitt dovrete far luce su alcuni avvenimenti strani, che però vi porteranno a brancolare in un'oscurità sempre più fitta. Se amate i racconti di Lovecraft non vi deluderà! Dopo aver giocato gratuitamente il primo episodio della prima stagione me ne sono innamorato subito!

La grafica è molto curata ed è in pixel art. Credo che questo stile renda i paesaggi e i personaggi più vaghi, lasciando che sia la nostra immaginazione a dipingere in modo vivido gli eventi inenarrabili di cui saremo testimoni.

La colonna sonora è davvero stupenda, con un forte uso di violini che accompagnano il protagonista nell'avventura creando l'atmosfera giusta. Inoltre il tema principale mi ha conquistato subito!

A livello di meccaniche di gioco, siamo di fronte ad un punta-e-clicca molto semplice. Gli oggetti possono essere osservati, usati o raccolti, il tutto usando semplicemente il tasto sinistro del mouse. Gli enigmi non sono mai particolarmente complessi, ma neanche banali. Risolverne uno lascia quel senso di orgoglio nell'aver usato solo il proprio intelletto per raggiungere la soluzione! Inoltre, non si possono raccogliere/usare oggetti se prima non si è scoperto qual è il loro uso. Questo costringe l'avanzare della storia in modo lineare, senza diventare mai dispersiva.
Ora, a mio parere ci sono vantaggi e svantaggi in questo senso:
- da una parte, non avremo mai molti oggetti nell'inventario né mille possibilità, per cui la soluzione non sarà mai troppo difficile da capire. Di solito, invece, nei punta-e-clicca si possono risolvere più enigmi contemporaneamente, rendendoli potenzialmente molto complessi.
- dall'altra, questo permette di non lasciarsi distrarre troppo dagli enigmi e dare più attenzione alla storia stessa.
Penso, quindi, che questa scelta sia molto azzeccata per questo gioco.
Come nota dolente cito lo scarso impatto dei dialoghi, in quanto sono molto limitati e, a mio parere, poco curati - però come realizzazione tecnica e non come contenuti. Insomma, non ho provato la classica gioia dei punta-e-clicca di parlare con un sacco di personaggi e poter scegliere che direzione dare alla discussione. Ma, di nuovo, potrebbe essere visto come un vantaggio in quanto permette di concentrarsi maggiormente sulla narrazione.

Se vi piacciono i punta-e-clicca e/o le avventure a tema Lovecraft, dovete giocarlo!

Nota personale finale: Io amo i punta-e-clicca e Lovecraft, oltre alla grafica in pixel-art. Sembra davvero un gioco fatto apposta per me e l'ho adorato! Inoltre (a essere onesto) è il primo punta-e-clicca che riesco a finire senza usare mai guide o aiuti esterni (anche se devo aggiungere che ci ho giocato con la mia ragazza e abbiamo collaborato per la soluzione degli enigmi). Sì, probabilmente non sono particolarmente sveglio, però mi è piaciuto questo equilibrio tra enigmi e storia e lo reputo un punto a favore!

Il y a à peine 5 minutes, je finissais la première saison de The Last Door. Et si je suis déjà entrain de rédiger mon avis sur le jeu, c'est bien parce que ce fut un gros coup de coeur. 
Bien sûr, comme n'importe quel avis, cela reste subjectif, c'est un ressenti propre, unique, et même si ça coule de source, je tiens à le préciser :)
Force est de constater que l'inspiration par les grands maîtres de l'horreur tel que Lovecraft et Poe est une réussite. Selon moi, peu d'oeuvres vidéoludique arrivent à retranscrire cette atmosphère si particulière, poisseuse et angoissante, mais les développeurs de The Game Kitchen ont su maîtrisé leurs classiques à la perfection. Les clins d'oeil sont nombreux et les plus connaisseurs d'entre vous comprendront de quoi je veux parler ;)
Pour moi, la bande son est une pure réussite. Que cela passe par un murmure incompréhensible, par les lamentations glaçantes d'un chat, par des grattements dans les murs, une note aïgue et angoissante lorsque l'on fait une macabre découverte où simplement par les sublimes musiques au piano et aux violons, le son donne le ton à l'atmosphère et contribue à nous refiler des frissons plus d'une fois. 

Pour ce qui est de l'histoire, c'est là aussi pour moi un point fort du jeu. On se retrouve à enchaîner les épisodes afin de s'engouffrer toujours un peu plus dans ce cauchemar malgré nous. L'intrigue n'est pas la plus folle et la plus alambiquée en soit, mais elle est prenante, bien narrée et la mise en scène est là pour glorifier le tout.

Et tant que je suis à faire des louanges à ce The Last Door, autant vous parler de la DA que j'ai trouvé magnifique. Les pixels bien que franchement grossiers sont sublimés par des jeux de lumières étonnamment bien foutu pour des graphismes de ce style et les décors sont joliment soignés.

La durée de vie est plutôt bonne, voir même honorable pour le prix (il m'a fallu un peu plus de 6h pour boucler la première saison).

Des défauts ? Honnêtement, je ne pourrais même pas en trouver tellement j'ai aimé l'expérience. Peut être que les afficionados du genre point'n click trouveront l'aventure un peu trop facile. Ah oui ! Un truc par contre, étant donné le style graphique du jeu, certains objets sont parfois difficiles à trouver, n'étant qu'un tout petit tas de pixel dans le tableau, et des fois on se retrouve à passer plusieurs fois une pièce en revu avant de trouver le dit objet, mais bon, rien de dramatique non plus. Mais..pour moi, c'est tout.

Je finirai en disant que The Last Door ne paie pas de mine comme ça, mais purée ! il a réussi à me foutre la frousse. Très franchement, jamais j'aurais pensé qu'un jeu au look 8bit arriverait à faire ça. Au mieux, je m'attendais à ce que l'ambiance générale donne quelque chose de mystérieux, voir inquiétant. Et pourtant. Je suis la première surprise à l'écrire, mais il a réussi à me foutre la boule au ventre plus d'une fois, pas comme un jumpscare facile et gratuit le ferait, plutôt comme une peur qui vous glace lentement le sang. Certains penseront que j'en fais trop, mais je vous assure, ce n'est pas le cas. En tout cas, cela à fonctionner sur moi, peut être que ça ne marchera pas autant sur d'autres, peut être que certains se retrouveront dans ce que je décris ;)

Bref, vous l'aurez compris, j'ai adoré cette première saison, c'est un de mes coup de coeur vidéoludiques de ces dernières semaines que je recommande vivement aux amateurs de jeux d'aventure à ambiance horrifique (trop rares selon moi) mais également aux fans de Lovecraft et Edgar Allan Poe. The Last Door - Collector's Edition is a point and click horror game about a man who tries to find out more about his childhood and what happened to his old friends after receiving a mysteriously vague letter from his friend. You have to make your way through an unsettling and dark 1890s London as you piece together a mystery full of well written characters, disturbing secrets and a haunting past filled to the top with the occult.

The game follows your classic point and click formula of walking around, clicking on small objects to pick them up and use later, and solving a whole bunch of puzzles. Personally, I thought many of the puzzles were very clever and interesting to try and understand, even though I couldn't make it through without using guides. This game is actually called "Collector's Edition" because it is the first of two seasons in the story, that consists of the first four episodes. All of the episodes are available to play for free online and I'm well aware of this, but I bought this game for 2 reasons, first one being my wish to support this developer, and also playing them all seperately with months between made it impossible to follow the story because I kept forgetting a lot of important details. This also comes with a few interesting shorts that tie up some looser ends of the story.

The story is definitely my favourite part of the game. You play as Jeremiah Devitt, a lonely philosophy teacher. One day, he receives a letter from his childhood friend Anthony, and the letter consists of a single line, the motto of a student group they formed together to discuss philosphy, science and art, who called themselves the four witnesses. As he tries to find out what happened to Anthony and the rest, as well as his own mysterious past, he starts to get haunted, and soon enough, there's no turning back.

The mystery in the story is presented in a way that you keep getting answers to your questions in each episode, but new questions keep arising all the time, having you constantly curious, but it is still possible to follow what's going on. The characters are also all very well made. The main character, Jeremiah Devitt is silent, polite and classy. This makes him somewhat easy to understand and relate with. My favourite character that plays a huge role in this game is probably Alexandre - he is intelligent, calm and, somehow, very sane and very insane at the same time. With the exception of doctor Wakefield, not a single character felt boring to me, and everyone had some mystery surrounding them.

Can't talk about a horror game without talking about the horror aspect, and this game manages to deliver very well. This game is based more on psychological horror than jump scares. Sure, there will be moments when dead silence is interrupted by someone slamming the piano, but there are plenty of very, very clever scares, with my favourite being the carnival disk from the first episode. The whole idea of something changing in a weird way when not looking is one that scares me a lot, and this game does that very well.

The one thing that seemingly many people like complaining about are the minimalistic pixel graphics. To me, the graphics were the second best thing in the game, right behind the story. Sure, the pixels are big and you're getting a sense of deja vu when introduced to a new character but his face is made of 10 pixels, like everyone else's, so telling them apart can be a real puzzle in itself, but other than that, the art is done really well. Each episode has its own colour palette, the lightning is used really well (and helps enhance the scares), and there's quite a lot of detail even if it's pixelated - take the intro for example. Sure, the game might seem lazy when a human doesn't have many details when looking from a distance, but the bigger objects are incredible - the close-ups of things (like in the intro), the buildings and backgrounds are done extremely well. The atmosphere is also incredible, being just what you would picture 1890s London like.

I also think this game's sound design is worth mentioning - not just because of the very chilling and fitting soundtrack (the intro music is by far my favourite and delivers just the right amount of unsettling feelings), but also because this is one of the only games I've played where I notice how well the sound effects are used. The jumpscares, for example - the carnival disk one does this perfectly. I once tried to listen to that song for as long as I could, but after a while it started sounding too devilish for me to go on. And the jumpscare part was reinforced by a nice slam on the piano. The game also uses suspenseful sounds on loop that get closer and closer as you approach something (meowing, pipes dripping, laughter etc.), and there's also my favourite - clever use of audio channels.

For completionists, the game's achievements are for finding secrets and reading notes - it won't take too long and won't be hard, but it did feel just a bit boring and the length was too short for me, but this is the type of game you should pick up if you only care about the percentage.

Overall, this game does mostly everything pretty well, but if you think the price is too much for a 5 hour game that you can play online, you should play it online or get it on sale because the bonus content is not too good.

As of this writing, I am up to Episode 3 and...

Words fail me...truly. 

I got this for the Lovecraftian tag that brought me face to face with this game. But the true essence of this game owes a deeper debt to the man whom Lovecraft called his "god of fiction": Edgar Allan Poe. You play a young man come to seek out a boyhood friend living in a remote estate out in the country (House of Usher, anyone?). Thanks to an interactive prologue that has to be seen to be believed, you already know what state your friend is going to be in when you find him. But that's just a clever feint. By the end of the episode, you find out that there is a lot more going on than you expected.

The amazing thing about this game to me is how it is able to accomplish so much with so little. It utilizes graphics that I would have expected from a 1980s Sierra adventure game that roughly approximate the look of the objects they represent. But then it combines it with a lush score that evokes its Gothic setting and fairly stellar sound effects that conjure up the required horror better than any graphics ever could. It's a trick that the developers borrowed from old time radio dramas (more recently utilized by the H.P. Lovecraft Historical Society for THEIR new-time radio adaptations): what you hear is always more horrible than what you see.

Puzzles are about as difficult as Sierra's classic run of Quest adventure games, albeit with a click UI. It involves a lot of pixel hunting, logic application and a willingness to use anything and everything on every possible location. You either love this or you don't.

The first episode is a little too overt in its Poe love. If you sat through a high school English lit class, you'll get most to all of the references. But subsequent episodes begin charting their own story course with plotting that recalls William Hope Hodgson's "House on the Borderland", Robert Chambers' "The King In Yellow" collection and the more uncanny stories of Ambrose Bierce. Yes, it also recalls Lovecraft himself but it's worth remembering that the authors I just mentioned influenced HPL in his own storytelling. At this point, I know I'm going to have to finish this game to figure out what's going on.

Oh and there is a special treat in the Extras menu. The Extras consist of vignettes that take place between chapters, driven by characters outside the main narrative. To avoid spoilers, I would recommend skipping these until you finish the game however.

All in all, it was well worth the slight cost involved to buy this game. If you're an old school adventure fan, highly recommended!

It's ...not great. The writing, inspired in equal parts by early HPL and his model, Poe, is predictable, formulaic, stiff, and at times some awkwardness emerges, making it clear this is a translation. The art-style, and its pixel count in particular, are a little too sparse, looking both too plain and not expressive enough (what am I looking at, exactly? the artistry in low-res pixel art is to make it pretty and immediately clear, without the benefit of detail - broad strokes!), there's UI/UX roughness as well. Starting with Episode 2, puzzles drift towards the obtuse (use a stone eagle, a net and a shower, plus a mirror, to make a statue cry and fool an otherwise down to earth, harsh nun into mystical rapture - oookay). Sound design is hit and miss, sometimes screaming FREESOUND.ORG at the top of its lungs, not in a good way, I mean.

All in all, it's a tough recommendation: the adventure bits are too contrived, and the story (and its telling) aren't compelling enough. Granted, nobody expects anything groundbreaking from homage, but homage itself cannot be [i]too[/i] hamfisted.

Unless any of this sounds exactly like something you would enjoy playing, steer away.

32706389.review:
[h1]An entertaining horror point and click adventure, somewhat marred by it's short length.  Definitely worth picking up if you see it on sale.[/h1]

  I enjoyed The Last Door quite a bit.  I didn't ever feel scared, but there was a little dread that creeped up on me.  Despite it's retro graphical style, the game manages to create an eldritch atmosphere of dark mystery, in no small part to it's amazing soundtrack by Carlos Viola.  I found myself wrapped up in the events, and questioning what was really going on, and what would happen next.  The main characters were fairly interesting, but I'll admit, because of the simpleness of the sprites, it can be easy to mistake who is who.  The notes hidden throughout the game are interesting and well written.  Upon completion of the game, I recommend going back with a guide and finding all the secrets, however, some are a little annoying to find.
  The soundtrack is excellent, and is provided in the game's local files.  These tracks are used exceptionally well to set the mood, and you will frequently hear new songs throughout your playthrough, even the first episode had a surprising number of song changes.  That being said, sometimes you would step outside, or into a new room, and the song that had just started would end abruptly.  It was a little jarring.
  Mechanically the game is pretty standard point and click.  The inventory and interactions are all up to par with modern games (something not all games with "classical" styles bless us with).  Most puzzles are easy, although you may pass some of the objects you need to interact with, seeing as two pixels could represent shading, a book, a note, a cup, etc.  The walking speed is also somewhat tedious, which could have been used to build tension, but I usually just felt bored while backtracking.  Speaking of which, for a game that only takes about four hours to complete, you certainly need to walk from on side of the map and back again an awful lot.  This is, thankfully subverted somewhat with the ability to instantly travel through certain doors you've previously been though via double clicking, and many of the locations have multiple paths which keep things a bit fresh.
  I'd like to note that while the pacing of the game was good, and the narrative was engaging, the short length left me without a feeling of closure, and not in an "I can't wait to see what happens next" sort of way, but in an "oh, we're ending it there hm?" sort of way.  I'm not really a fan of the episodic format to begin with, and I may have felt disapointed if I hadn't purchased this game on sale.  I will give the game credit for using the episodes well, I can remember each one distinctly, and it never really felt like I spent to long in one location.  Each episode felt unique, which I'm all for.
  [b]All in all, I do recommend this game, but if you want more bang for your buck, wait for it to go on sale.[/b]

Let's get the most pressing issue out of the way first.

The art style is stupid and gimmicky. There is nothing retro about it, even the Sierra AGI adventure games from the 80s had higher resolution than this garbage. And don't even get me started with mixing different pixel sizes. Nothing ever lines up pixel-perfectly, fonts, inventory and the game use all different pixel resolutions. It looks horrible and the developers should feel bad for doing so. I love pixel art, but this game completely fails to deliver on that end. Just make a text adventure next time.

Gameplaywise, it's a great adventure game with a solid and chilling story, especially if you like Chzo Mythos games or Lovecraftian horror in general. The puzzles leave a bit to be desired, but I didn't really expect hard puzzles from this game in the first place. Music and sound effects bring much life to this game and are easily the most memorable aspect of it.

I feel that The Last Door could've been much more and now it remains a forgettable curiosity and a small one evening distraction. Sane art direction and a more complex and captivating puzzle system would've made this a modern adventure game classic.

Ultimately a bit disappointing, but I suppose I'd still recommend it for the exemplary audio design and atmosphere.

J'ai découvert The Last Door grâce à la vidéo d'un youtuber.
Le jeu me paraissait intéressant alors quand il s'est retrouvé soldé sur Steam, je me suis lancé.

Il s'agit d'un jeu d'aventure (point and click).
De prime abord, c'est vrai, les graphismes du jeu surprennent. C'est très pixelisé certes (et c'est certainement voulu), mais cela n'empêche pas le jeu d'avoir un certain charme et surtout de dégager une ambiance géniale. Disons que l'on s'y habitue rapidement.

C'est sombre, glauque, intriguant, inquiétant. C'est extrèmement bien mis en scène par l'intermédiaire de flash back ou de changement de protagoniste. 

L'ambiance sonore et la musique sont réellement de haut niveau et renforce l'immersion. C'est pour moi le gros point fort du jeu, avec son scénario bien sûr.

L'intrigue avance doucement, au rythme de la résolution des énigmes qui nous sont proposées. Une sombre histoire d'expérience réalisée par des étudiants à la fin du 19ème siècle en Ecosse.
La progression dans le jeu est découpée en épisode, avec les codes habituelles auxquels on est habitué dans les séries TV (générique de début, "précédemment dans Last Door", cliffhanger de fin d'épisode). 
Le jeu n'est pas basé sur la succession de Screamer, mais plutôt sur une histoire bien ficellée et racontée avec talent.

Vous en verrez la fin au bout de 5-6 heures, en prenant le temps d'apprécier l'ambiance et en lisant tous les indices qui seront mis sur votre chemin.
C'est court, c'est vrai, mais vous passerez un bon moment à suivre cette histoire et vous voudrez probablement enchainer sur la saison 2 (pour info, il existe un pack contenant les 2 jeux sur Steam).


Et j'allais oublier, les textes sont en français et la traduction est remarquable.

Un achat que je ne regrette pas, vous l'aurez compris.

Before reviewing the game itself, I want to note that the soundtrack with this is amazing. I liked it enough, in fact, that I went to bandcamp and bought the remastered version for both the first and second seasons. It is one of those listens you can enjoy without having it connected to a game, and that accentuates your game-related experience. Even if the game were mediocre, I would get it for that. 

Thankfully, the game is great as well. 

If you have never played a point-and-click game, the objective is simple. Explore your surroundings by clicking to tell whoever/whatever you are controlling where to go/what to pick up/what to sample, figure out puzzles, and enjoy the ride. It is something that a gaming novice can get into, and that any skill level can enjoy. This is actually a great medium for this type of horror, because it helps establish a sense of dread while luring you deeper into whatever puzzle awaits. 

The graphics also work for this, which honestly surprised me, although there are places when a little clarity would assist with puzzles. For example, finding a path in a heap of blocks is sometimes more difficult than it sounds and I managed to get lost a couple of times because of this. This does not harm the game, however, and some things are actually pretty cool to see displayed along a "less is more" approach. There are some solid combinations of sound and visuals presented, too, and they are somewhat frightening. You can see that in the first chapter, and it develops from there. 

You can try out the first portions of this for free on the creator's sites, so try it out if you are wondering. Give the medium a chance, too, even if you are torn on it or have played it before and had mixed or negative results, because there is a lot here. Also, you can find other games that use this format and that also add to the horror/comic terror format.

[olist]
[*]先说说画面。对我来说，恐惧感在视觉上的冲击并不如心理上的暗示来的汹涌，而这款游戏正切这一要素。在我看来，低像素的画风（是已经低到你开始怀疑自己的视力）与这类Lovecraftian真的是完美契合，因为太过具象化的描写都会让由自己想像力所催生的恐惧变得触手可及，而一个我能看得到的恐怖，其杀伤力会大打折扣。由于画面的模糊不清，很多元素都可以理解成是抽象化的表达。这样我就有了充足的想象空间，这种由自身想像所渲染恐惧感，要比那些靠画面和特效所输入的恐惧感强烈得多。

[*]再说说音乐。整体配乐的风格与故事所处的时代背景配合的很好，场景转换时音乐的突变更是让我汗毛竖立，总感觉有未知的邪恶会从黑暗中袭来。小小地剧透一下，在触发留声机事件的时候，整个人都不由自主的打了个哆嗦。或哀伤，或紧张，或迷惘，游戏的原声音乐都能很好地带动我的情绪，让我能更好地沉浸在其所创造的氛围中。

[*]然后是游戏性。在操作上，这是一个只用鼠标就能愉快玩耍的点击冒险解密游戏，所以只要你会点击鼠标左键（触摸板也可以啦），剩下的就只是解决谜题和体会游戏了。对于游戏机制，正如前面所说的，这游戏主要是靠氛围的渲染和隐晦的剧情让我感受到恐惧，所以那种突然出现的一惊一乍式的桥段并不存在（啊）。在支离破碎的线索被一点点拼凑起来，游戏所带来的那种压迫感也会越来越强烈。
[/olist]

[u]以上均为个人的喜好与经验之谈，因为这类心理恐怖惊悚游戏真的是因人而异。[/u][i]日后应该还会有修改。[/i]

31041605.review:
Aventura gráfica 2D de estética pixel en la cual nos pondremos en el papel de Jeremiah Devitt, un joven que recibe una extraña carta de un antiguo amigo de la infancia, en esta nuestro protagonista se verá asolado por la duda causada por la inusual naturaleza del mensaje y decidirá emprender un viaje que le llevará a lo más profundo de su ser y a encontrar las más horribles de las verdades ocultas a la vista del hombre.

Con este inusual argumento el juego nos sumerge en una apasionante aventura cargada de suspense y terror donde la investigación y la toma de decisiones toman el papel principal dentro de un marco de ambientación Lovecraftiana. El título se sirve de varios aspectos dentro de los que destacan sus gráficos de estilo pixel art difuminativo, los cuales enmarcan a la perfección un contexto y un desarrollo totalmente envolventes gracias a elementos como sus preciosos escenarios, que asombran por su buen acabado y perfecto detalle, su banda sonora, que brilla por su impecable elegancia y  su jugabilidad, basada  en el "ponit and click" clásico y con una intrefaz pulcra e intuitiva.

Como elementos a reprochar solo podemos poner de manifiesto su escasa duración, que sumada a su elevado coste y al hecho de encontrar el juego fraccionado en dos temporadas hace discutible su compra al precio estipulado, no por contra hay que dejar de lado su impresionante valor tanto a nivel artístico como argumental, pues este ofrece de sobra una calidad suficiente como para ensalzar sus virtudes más allá de su coste, no obstante no puedo dejar de recomendar su compra en pack y con descuento.

Como nota final remarcar el cuidado y detalle puestos en el juego así como su maravillosa atmosfera, que nos pondrá en tensión en más de una ocasión ofreciéndonos una grata experiencia a la altura de las expectativas y en donde los aficionados al género encontrarán una nueva joya que incluir en su repertorio de títulos predilectos. Altamente recomendable.

[h1]"Видишь?"[/h1]

Что такое тайна? Некий азарт, который манит любопытный глаз игрока своей неизведанностью и, в то же время, устрашает. Загадка, дающая своему участнику чувство первооткрывателя, чувство важности и уникальности. Но зачастую, тот, кто берётся за разгадку, начинает испытывать на подсознательном уровне чувство тревоги и дискомфорта. Первобытные чувства перед неправильностью происходящего. Создатели игры черпали вдохновение у таких бессмертных писателей, как Э. А. По ([spoiler]Ворон; Чёрный кот; Падение дома Ашеров; Преждевременные похороны[/spoiler]), Г. Ф. Лавкрафта ([spoiler]Крысы в стенах; Серебряный ключ [/spoiler]) и др. А также не обошёл стороной культовый сериал Д. Линча "Твин Пикс" ([spoiler]Красная комната; Занавес; Реверсивная речь[/spoiler]). Из таких внушительных ингридиентов разработчикам удалось создать уникальный в своём роде микс-коктейль, оставляющий после себя приятное послевкусие. Честно говоря, я не ожидал получить от игры в два раза больше впечатлений чем планировалось.

Сюжет: Октябрь 1891 года. Энтони Бичворт пишет послание своему лучшему другу, - Videte ne quis sciat, - а после, в пребывании полного отчуждения, отчаяния и страха - кончает жизнь самоубийством на своём чердаке путём самоповешения. Джеремайя Девитт - главный протагонист истории, получает письмо и осознаёт, что что-то плохое случилось с его другом. Долго не раздумывая, он тут же садится на ближайший поезд и отправляется в его загородное поместье. Близится осенний вечер; холодный ветер навевает жуткий настрой. Добравшись до пункта назначения, Джеремайя впутывается в череду тёмных, странных и жутких событий, которые зародились ещё очень давно.

P.S - приключения продолжаются во втором сезоне.  

Геймплей: P'n'C жанр, построенный на несложных логических пазлах, которые приятно решать. Первый сезон разделён на четыре маленькие главы, в которых протагонисту придётся побывать в "место-действие" локациях и, собственно, принять в них участие. Помимо решения различных ситуаций, которые двигают сюжет, игроку будет предоставлена маленькая возможность выбора (!), как в диалогах, так и в моральных аспектах. Но на сюжет это абсолютно никак не влияет, а лишь привносит приятное разнообразие в геймплей.

Саундтрек: Музыка и звуки на твёрдую пятёрку! Великолепную оркестровую музыку написал Карлос Вайола, который смог задать правильное настроение игре и её истории: захватывающую, пугающую, меланхолическую и создающую чувство саспенса. В дополнении к отличной музыке (которая идёт бесплатным подарком к игре) - чистые звуки, заставляющие тебя поверить в то, что всё происходит наяву (играть в наушниках). Прекрасная работа! 

Графика: Инди пиксель арт не хватающий звёзд с неба, но имеющий отличную визуальную составляющую с вниманием к мелочам и хорошо проработанным разнообразием мест. Атмосфера и погружение работают безотказно.

Итог: Один из тех примеров, который показывает, какой должна быть инди-игра: всё продумано, прописано, и главное - реализовано как надо. В сочетании с визуальной и аудиосоставляющей прохождение становится увлекательным, а сюжет  интригует и держит в напряжении, местами добротно пугая! Советую брать на скидке или в другом И-магазине (как сделал я). Моя оценка: 4/5.

30560954.review:
Carlos Viola deserves a lot of credit for an excellent score.

After that, I fail to see what any of the fuss is about.

The first thing you notice is the writing.  It's stilted and flat, in what may be an attempt to mimic period dialogue but instead comes off as insincere at best.  Playing off all-too-common tropes of abandoned text scattered everywhere, animals being weird, and an explosive case of amnesia, vast portions of the game just feel forced.  The characters aren't coherent and motivations seem to change between episodes.  This isn't about an Unreliable Narrator or the mysteries that lie behind the adventure; the writing is fraught with such problems it simply challenges your ability to stay immersed at all.

Stuff just happens.  Spookily, I suppose you'd say.  Spooky stuff.

All of this adds up to a storyline that's just been ripped straight from HPL's "Rats in the Walls" and Rob Zombie's "Lords of Salem" between extended bouts of coveting Ben Croshaw's 10 year old Chzo Mythos.


Adventure fans won't find much here, either.  Puzzles are trivial when not adolescent, and inventory choices make sure to slick your gears as soon as possible.  The whole experience was over in under 3 hours, and I'm simply disappointed by it.

29683410.review:
The Last Door is a horror point-and-click set in a victorian setting inspired by the works of Edgar Allan Poe and H.P Lovecraft. 
I normally avoid point-and-click games alongside graphic adventures, why? Because this games are usually in extreme cryptic, where you end up clicking everything or reading a guide in order to beat the game.
The Last Door is an exception to that rule, here the puzzles are more intuitive and logical than anything, if you pay attention to the game and think logically about it you will easily solve most of the puzzles of the game. That's not the case for every [b]episode[/b] of the game however. Yes, it's an episodic game and I consider it a mistake, I mean, the game is linear, episode 2 goes right after episode 1, I think it's pointless to divide the game's events in 4 episodes if what happens in those 4 episodes happens in a linear way, yeah I know the game was originally sold through episodes but it's a collection, you can simply put them together. Another problem I find is through episodes 3 and 4 where the things stop being intuitive and logical and become more cryptic. For example there is a part where you need a red lightbulb, you have the lightbulb BUT in order to get the red stuff to paint it you need to go back at a previous location and the game doesn't tell you, you literally have zero reasons to go back at that area.
They are more present in chapter 4 than everything.
Another thing that bothers me is that the game does build up a creepy atmosphere and tension, BUT there is always one or two jumoscares, the cheapest expression of horror, there are about 1 or 2 in every episode and at the most obvious places you would expect, it brokes the tension and atmosphere that the game built.
I don't have any complains story wise, I think everything flows perfectly through the game, yeah there are small parts where the game feels a little convinient but that would be nitpicking from my part as this scenes are usually insignificant, it's quite the good creepy story with lovecraftian-like elements I only have 2 problems with this story:
[b]The Protagonist[/b]
Despite saying that one of the main appeals is to bury ourselves into the mysteries of his psyche. Jeremiah Devitt is the most bland, boring guy you can imagine, he's as average as your average Joe. He's a guy who's entire dialogue is based around describing stuff, I don't what he likes, what does he think of himself, heck I barely even know the guy at all, I can't think on a small description about the guy. In other graphic adventures and point-and-click games the main protagonist has at least a bit of personality and charisma, think Guybrush of Monkey Island or think Fran Bow of... Fran bow, you know how the dudes are and they make the journey a bit more pleasant.
[b]The ending[/b]

29444083.review:
The world is not what it seems. There is a threshold between this world and the next. The last door awaits...

It's an amazing feat how many emotions these developers managed to conjure up from as few pixels as possible. Make no mistake, this is a scary game. It'll draw you into its Lovecraftian world of loss, madness and fear over the course of the four episodes, and the foreboding atmosphere it builds up over their course is in a league of its own.

It's difficult to describe how this game manages to be scary to those who have not played it. It's due to the phenomenal story for the most part, but also the masterful sound design. As events take a turn for the worse, you'll hear howling behind walls or singing from someone who isn't there or hear footsteps following you.

Perhaps ironically, this game isn't one that'll force you to go on a pixel hunt for the next item. It's very clear what you can and cannot use, what items to combine, and what interactions you have left. Usually, in a point and click game, I'll resort to using a walkthrough for one part at least, but this wasn't the case with The Last Door. These developers took their time to make it accessible for all types of players. It's clear how much they cared for this project.

Kudos to Carlos Viola for the brilliant soundtrack. Not only does it work perfectly for this game, but I've found it atmospheric enough to listen to while reading horror. It's far more listenable when a horror game goes for a memorable soundtrack, rather than a generic scary one. "Crows over the city" is probably the best theme tune for a horror game I've heard.

By the time I got to the final episode, I was hopelessly hooked on this series, but I wanted to turn it off because that episode is terrifying. There's an achievement called "The Angels Protect This House", that I'd suggest reading before playing the final episode. It made me dread playing it, and I promise you, you'll dread turning your back on them.

I'd suggest this game to anyone remotely interested in Lovecraft, or fear of the unknown.

29354039.review:
Even though the first chapter of the first season is available for free online, its atmosphere doesn't remotely scratch the surface of the incredibly vast range of feelings that the series causes the player to experience - admittedly, most of the emotions revolving around the core feeling of horror.

The Last Door is a game that should be left completely unspoiled, and even if I tried to ruin someone's joy of experiencing this dark journey for themselves, there is an immense amount of lore, events, and characters to it, so it would be incredibly difficult to even semi-accurately reflect the brilliance of this series.

The game is not only praised by me for its story and writing - don't get me wrong, I'd still claim it to be one of the best puzzle or horror games I've ever played with other elements being sub-par. It isn't, however, the case with The Last Door. I tried to find flaws with the game and couldn't find anything that everyone could agree with it being a flaw. Let me begin with the things that some people could find undesirable:

-No voice-overs. Sure, some people are lazy and don't want to read much. To those people I can only say - fair enough. However, even if you don't enjoy reading because it might bore you, I very much doubt that The Last Door will make you not want to read the dialogues or notes that you may stumble upon, as they help uncover the story in an incredibly fascinating way. If you're still reading this - perfect. Now on to why I don't think that the lack of voice-overs is an issue. It leaves you, the player, free to assign all the characters your own imaginary voices - perhaps to you one character sounds rough and strong, while to someone else they might sound sensitive and caring, judging by their words. There is also always a chance that voices would damage the game's atmosphere, as without them, the player can listen to The Last Door's music - there is a plethora of tracks, all of them carefully composed to suit the atmosphere of the location the player is in.

-Jumpscares. Some people enjoy them, some don't. I belong to the group of the latter. The amount of them in the game is very low, and I have to admit that they're really well-executed, even though I got scared by none of them. However, they do help shape the atmosphere of the location and after the initial feeling of being caught off-guard has passed, the player is left with being disturbed by what had happened.

Now, with cons out of the way, let me go over the pros!
-The audio. I love music - I'm absolutely fascinated by it, from composing and playing to listening to it. Music can be really beautiful and stimulating; it can cause us to feel different emotions and get us in different moods. It can illustrate the atmosphere of something or some situation better than any words ever could. That is precisely what The Last Door's soundtracks do. Apart from being mostly extremely enjoyable to listen to due to their composition and execution, they set the feeling that locations or events carry with them. The ones that aren't extremely enjoyable? Those would be the few tracks that are really dissonant (i.e. they make you wince when you listen to them, which doesn't make them bad per se, mind you. For example try playing or looking up a tritone, which is a very much dissonant interval) and are not to be enjoyed, but they create this really haunting atmosphere.

-The graphics. It seems that a lot of people are divided here; The Last Door's graphics are really pixelated by design. Sure, it is sometimes difficult to make out what is what, I suppose, even though it never prevented me or made it more difficult for me to progress. Personally, I really enjoy that stylistic choice. Not because I am a fan of pixelated graphics, I usually prefer it when there is a lot of detail. So why do I enjoy this world of pixels? Again, it's because it leaves you, the player, free to interpret what's going on - to shape the looks of the locations and chaaracters for yourself. What you see on the screen is merely a canvas with a few outlines, and your mind is the brush, completing the painting. You can never see the face of any character, and so you're left to imagine whaat they look like for yourself, to shape their looks the way you believe fits best, and I find that amazing.

-The storyline (spoiler-free). *Page left intentially blank*

-The characters (spoiler-free). Every person that appears in the game has their own personality, even ones that barely speak or interact with the player. You are guaranteed to find some characters that you will like, and some that you will hate, most likely the moment you read their first line of dialogue. They also look different in terms of appearance, even though they're heavily pixelated. The player can also learn more about many of them through reading various notes that can be found in the game's world. I'd love to elaborate, but then spoilers would inevitably occur.

-The controls. Well, it's point and click, so a mouse is all you need. You just click on objects, you can combine some of them, and so on. There's no dragging, quick-time events, or anything else. You just click to move your character around, go to different locations, and interact with your surroundings. Really straight-forward.

-The puzzles. At first you might get stuck here and there occasionally, not knowing what to do. You might need to look up guides to just learn where you're supposed to use that one item you have to progress because you're utterly lost. After a while, hopefully sooner than later, you will get used to the puzzles and will have much less difficulty figuring out what to do. It may temporarily damage the immersion, but it might very well be just me who got stuck a few times, not knowing what to do. It is, of course, possible to figure it all out without any guide, but they're there, just in case you might need them.



*TL;DR/Conclusion here*

So, what do I think of The Last Door? In short, it's a game that has left me stunned and longing for more, for some game or any other medium that would make me feel similar emotions to the ones I felt while playing this one. It made me at times scared, or feeling sympathy towards certain characters, while despising others, all while I was well-aware that they are perfectly fictional. However, two emotions that were constantly there while I was playing The Last Door were being disturbed to a various degree, and the utter curiosity to discover what was waiting for me next.

Thank you for reading my review, and I wish you a good day.

29085460.review:
[Este análisis se aplica a ambas temporadas del juego]

Hace unos años, seguía de cerca el desarrollo de este juego, nada más salió el primer episodio. Recuerdo que cuando salió el 2º episodio, dejaron el 1º gratis para que todos lo jugaran, e hicieron depués lo mismo con el 2 y el 3. Menciono esto para hacer ver que la gente que creó esta obra lo hicieron con mucha pasión y ganas. Era fácil encontrarte con cualquiera de los desarrolladores por los foros y comentarles cualquier cosa.

Ahora que está todo terminado, solo queda decir que su esfuerzo ha merecido sin duda la pena, ya que este juego es sin duda una de las experiencias más memorables y absorbentes que he tenido el placer de experimentar.

[h1]Historia[/h1]

Inglaterra, 1891

Jeremiah Devitt recibe una carta de su antiguo compañero y amigo Anthony Beechworth, advirtiéndole de un inminente peligro. Éste se dirige a la residencia Beechworth, y nada más llegar ahí, comienza la aventura. No diré nada concreto, por no desvelar más de la historia, pero la búsqueda de Devitt de la verdad le llevará por las más lúgubres y macabras esquinas de una Inglaterra Victoriana repleta de las más retorcidas leyendas. Desde internados hasta hospitales, pasando por pueblos que se toman demasiado en serio su folklore y hasta lugares más allá de los confines de la realidad.

The Last Door respira la obra de H.P. Lovecraft y demás autores de su círculo y deja que ésta imbuya una atmósfera tétrica, perfecta para una historia tan psicológicamente siniestra. No es el típico juego de terror donde miedo=susto en cada esquina, TLD deja que el propio escenario y la situación acechen por sí solos. Les deja respirar y adquirir presencia. Hay un par de sustos a lo largo de la trama, sí, pero se los gana a pulso. No es un Slender.

[h1]Jugabilidad[/h1]

TLD es una aventura gráfica 'point & click'. No hay verbos ni acciones, sino que la interacción está limitada a mirar, recoger objetos, y usarlos con algo del escenario o con otro objeto mismo del inventario. Es muy minimalista en su interfaz, lo cual también hace que los puzles sean más fáciles, pero esto juega a favor de la ya mencionada atmósfera, ya que el juego está más enfocado a que disfrutes la historia a que te pases 2 horas colgado.

Dicho esto, los puzles como tal se integran muy bien en la historia, y en ningún momento se siente como algo artificial, o como que el juego 'te bloquea' (no hay que encontrar 3 emblemas para abrir la puerta del baño, por ejemplo).

En compensación por la 'falta de desafío', el juego tiene un puñado de 'secretos' que tienes que descubrir por tu cuenta. Esto hace que estés más atento al escenario y complementa bien la linealidad de la trama, aunque tampoco le da rejugabilidad. No hay contenido ni posibilidades que den para más de una segunda partida.

Cada episodio es una localización diferente, la cual exploramos y descubrimos sus recovecos. En la 1ª temporada, éstas son más 'contenidas', pero en la 2ª se amplían a niveles de pueblos enteros, lo cual deja paso a mayores y más complejos puzles, para los que hayáis esprintado los primeros episodios. Vamos, que se nota la progresión de la trama y el aspecto clímatico conforme te acercas al final.

Además, el aspecto episódico del juego permite que se pueda disfrutar en sesiones más cortas, lo cual nunca va mal.

[h1]Presentación[/h1]

Este es el aspecto que puede echar atrás a varios, el 'pixel art'. Pero dejadme deciros que la manera en la que está hecho es fantástica. Aunque sea pixel art, el nivel de detalle de los fondos y escenarios es (irónicamente) muy profundo y cuidado. Los gráficos no serán los mejores, pero el diseño artístico es una maravilla, lo cual se nota más en la 2ª temporada conforme los escenarios se abren más.

Y cualquier duda que quede es disipada con la banda sonora de Carlos Viola (la cual viene incluida, de hecho). Tanto ésta como el diseño de sonido en general rellenan los huecos que los gráficos dejan, y te permite sumergirte en la atmósfera.

[h1]Conclusión[/h1]

The Last Door es un título indie que, ofreciendo una inolvidable historia y atmósfera, cumple con sus ambiciones más allá de los recursos propios de un AAA. Si te gusta una buena historia de terror a la luz de una hoguera (o los relatos de Lovecraft) te encantará este juego. Incluso si no te van las aventuras gráficas, es muy accesible para novatos, pero veteranos que busquen un desafío o un reto puede que no se sientan satisfechos.

8.5/10

Before I review this game, I'd like to give information about myself (the reviewer) first.
I've been playing point & click games since 1990 on Commodore64, Amiga, PC and own quite a large collection. 

The product review is for the first season game, which I've played from the beginning to the end.

Visual: While most of you may not like the pixel graphics, I did like them in the game. It didn't bother me at all and actually I was quite impressed as to how much detail you can see in the pixel art itself. If you played one of the old Lucas Arts series in the early 90s before and you loved it, you'll love this one too. The effort of detail and coloured contrast they put in, gives it a beautiful realistic look, but yet it preserves the feel of a retro classic point & click game.

Audio: High quality stereo sound, the sound fx are moving from one ear to another as you're moving your character. The music gives also the atmosphere of a "creepy" game, since it's been designed to be a little scary. Melodies / music are somewhat similar to what you would expect in an old-fashioned horror movie. There are no character voices, just pure background music and sound effects.

If you have a slight interest in this point & click game / adventure, I highly recommend it.

28686432.review:
The Last Door es un juego bastante curioso, ya que tiene unos puntos fuertes muy marcados y unos no tanto.

Realmente intento ser lo más objetivo posible a la hora de valorar lo bueno o no que me ha parecido un juego, y nunca me dejo llevar por su aspecto gráfico, ni para bien ni para mal. Algo que parece estar muy de moda. Valorar un juego mucho más si su historia es buena y su apartado técnico gráfico es bastante limitado, y eso siendo generoso.

Es decir, no voy a considerar a este juego mejor de lo que es porque tenga una buena historia con unos gráficos simplemente horrendos. No quiero que se me entienda mal, me encantan los juegos tipo pixel art. Los juegos de Wadjet Eye Games son un claro ejemplo: Primordia, Gemini Rue, Resonance y muchísimos otros son grandes obras con estilo Pixel Art adaptado al día de hoy.

The Last Door no es así. Esto es pasarse directamente. Las caras de los personajes son 5 pixeles, literalmente. El personaje puede describirte lo que hay en un cuadro y decirte que es un ángel y tú no ves más que un emborronamiento de píxeles.

El aspecto gráfico es simplemente nefasto, y eso no lo convierte en mejor juego ni mucho menos. Sobre todo si juegas en una pantalla de 24 pulgadas como es mi caso.

Por otro lado el apartado sonoro es fabuloso, la atmósfera que recrea es magnífica y tanto música como efectos van de la mano para llevar al jugador a un entorno que resulta creíble y misterioso. La labor realizada en este caso es de muy alta factura.

En lo que respecta a su historia, yo la he encontrado bastante entretenida, pero tampoco la veo una maravilla. Es decir, lo que se nos cuenta está bastante bien, pero depende de con qué lo comparemos. Si lo comparamos con lo que suele salir hoy en día en su mayoría, es una argumentación notable, pero si lo comparamos con juegos de su mismo estilo como Shadow of the Comet por ejemplo, The Last Door sale perdiendo, y por mucho.

Y no solo en ese caso. Coge cualquiera de los Sherlock Holmes como El escalpelo mellado, The Awakened, The Testament o Jack el Destripador y la argumentación en cualqueira de estos juegos es muchísimo mejor, mucho más misteriosa y mucho más redonda que la historia que cuenta The Last Door.

En el aspecto jugable el juego es fácil de cojones. Quedarse bloqueado es práctivcamente imposible y su duración no irá más allá de las 4 horas. Lo cual en este aspecto pues es un tanto limitado.

Además es inconcluso, lo cual te obliga a comprar su segunda parte si quieres saber como acaba la historia, si es que acaba con la segunda que tampoco estoy seguro de ello.

En definitiva, historia interesante sin ser magnífica ni mucho menos, grandísima factura sonora, pésima calidad gráfica con gráficos de, literalmente, un Atari 2600, jugabilidad facilona y una duración bastante corta.

Si este juego hubiera tenido unos gráficos "normales" a buen seguro no se lo consideraría tan maravilloso como se lo considera. La historia ya no sería tan magnífica, la duración sería un motivo de queja, su facílidad insultante un problema, ni el trabajo en general sería tan soberbio. Lo cual no deja de resultar curioso.

Aún así, ¿recomiendo su compra? Pues en oferta sí, porque el juego no está mal y entretiene unas horas. Eso sí, siempre y cuando ya tengas jugados grandes clásicos del mismo estilo tipo Shadow of the Comet, o los arriba mencionados. Si no, ve antes a por los otros porque son mucho mejores.

28628009.review:
Una obra de arte, un homenaje a los clásicos de la literatura de terror y una aventura gráfica de vieja escuela que deja muy buen sabor de boca y te deja con ganas de más.

Pero sobre todo una muestra de cómo con muy pocos medios pero con muchas ganas e imaginación se pueden hacer las cosas realmente bien. De como con el pixel art, una estupenda banda sonora y unos buenos efectos sonoros se puede conseguir una ambientación brutal y una narración realmente cojonuda. 

Y todo con pixeles como puños, de los que se salen de la pantalla. 

Al más puro estilo de los clásicos literarios en los que se inspira, la aventura se ambienta en una Inglaterra Victoriana  donde capitulo a capitulo, capa a capa, iremos desentrañando una oscura trama que incluye inexplicables suicidios, morbosos asesinatos, sectas siniestras, deidades primigenias y sobre todo misterio, mucho misterio y terror. 

La aventura se divide en cuatro capítulos diferentes y funciona como si de una caja de bombones se tratase. Con cada situación y cada personaje del juego nos vamos a encontrar ante un nuevo bombón que no sabremos a que sabe hasta que lo hayamos probado y veamos de qué va la cosa. Pequeñas delicatessen, explosiones de sabor que van salpicando la aventura, a veces incluso sin tener nada que ver con la trama principal, y que elevan el juego a la categoría de pequeña obra de arte. 

En sí mismo, el juego es bastante fácil y llevadero. No va a suponer ningún reto real para el jugador pero es que esa no es su intención. El formato de aventura gráfica no es más que la excusa elegida para narrar una interesante historia de terror que busca sugerir más que mostrar y sobre todo permitir que la imaginación del jugador rellene los vacíos que va dejando el juego. 

Una pequeña maravilla... que lamentablemente nos va a dejar a medias hasta que juguemos a la segunda temporada y desentrañemos el misterio final. 

Poe, Lovecraft, Machen, Maupassant y Borges han sido los autores que han inspirado este juego. En serio... ¿ a qué esperas para jugarlo ?. 

Juego imprescindible para según qué paladares y recomendable en general para aquellos que busquen algo más en los juegos aparte de la simple diversión.


8/10

The Last Door does what it can with what it has. How much enjoyment you get out of this game is entirely up to your personal preferences. Being crowdfunded on a relatively small budget gives the game both advantages and disadvantages. The biggest advantage being that the game is very tightly knit, I encountered no bugs or soft locks while playing. However, in my opinion the disadvantages that come with a small budget outweigh this advantage. A small budget leaves relatively no room for polish, this makes for some of the cheesiest and expected jump scares I have encountered in the horror genre. This has nothing to do with aesthetic, its timing and predictability. (I’ve played Clock Tower which is a good counter example of how a little polish goes a long way in the horror genre). A small budget also makes the game linear, devoid even of any perceived choice in both the narrative and the puzzle solving, all of the puzzles have one solution and most of the time the item will disappear immediately after one use. 

           The Last Door occasionally suffers from obscure puzzle solutions (like any game of this genre) SPOILERS: [spoiler] The worst offender is in chapter 2 where for some reason you have to trick a nun into leaving her post by faking a miracle using a glass teardrop and a mirror on a statue of the Virgin Mary that does not have any descriptors indicating that the glass tear drop fits into her face.[/spoiler]  On the same note this game suffers from the typical point and click trope of “you have A SOLUTION but it is not MY SOLUTION” SPOILERS: [spoiler] The worst of it also being in chapter 2 where you have a glass mirror shard, a needle, a pointed gemstone, a rock, a sharp metal tool and rope netting that you could use to affix any of these sharp things to a stick to cut through a tapestry but you have to wait until you get a razor blade to move ahead.[/spoiler]  That being said, nothing was a terrible pixel hunt which I feel is the worst way to extend gameplay in a point and click genre.

            Overall, this game is a pretty meh way to spend an afternoon. You'd be better off spending your money elsewhere. I would not purchase this game at full price. Two to Three dollars is probably a fairer price for this game.

Когда я играл было не легко распознавать предметы в пикселях так как  не особо люблю пиксельные игры. Ну ладно давайте начнём обзор этой замечательной игры.

The Last Door — один в один как рассказ Эдгара По, фрагмент из которого попал в эпиграф. Но для нас, в отличие от главного героя, эта история начинается отнюдь не с письма давнего друга. Для нас она начинается с самоубийства.

По эту сторону

The Last Door вполне отвечает определению, данному квестам Августином Кордесом, создателем Scratches: «Мы можем просто сказать: «Я хочу рассказать эту историю!», а затем придумать под нее игровой дизайн. В таких условиях наш жанр работает лучше всего». Эта история прямолинейна и не допускает ветвлений сюжета, что, казалось бы, должно успокаивать. Ведь если персонажу что-то суждено каноном игры — этого не избежать, а значит, невозможно совершить ошибку, которая обернется чем-нибудь фатальным. Должно, но — и это удивительно! — отчего-то совершенно не успокаивает. Перед нами полноценный хоррор, и с созданием подобающей атмосферы разработчики справились безупречно.
Как и в Scratches, погружаться в мир неприглядных тайн, обманчивых туманов и прошлого, которое временами пытается подменить собой настоящее, игроку предстоит постепенно. Поначалу Джереми Дэвитт, только-только вошедший в дом своего старого друга и не обнаруживший там ни единой живой души, выглядит и действует как совершенно здравомыслящий, даже слегка меланхоличный взрослый человек. Он вообще, кажется, не склонен к проявлениям бурных эмоций и лишь пару раз, в особых случаях, позволяет себе ошеломленно воскликнуть. Но чем дальше, тем сложнее нам будет отделить реальность от галлюцинаций, а мистику — от результата экспериментов с химическими веществами. Это викторианская Англия, невозможная как без научных достижений, так и без духовных исканий, способных куда только не завести пытливый разум.
Первый сезон The Last Door составляют четыре эпизода, которых в сумме хватает часов на шесть-семь. Последний из них, вопреки всем надеждам хоть немного разобраться в творящемся безумии, лишь умножает неопределенность. Герой в прямом и в переносном смысле уходит в туман, не удосужившись поделиться с нами ни своими выводами касательно произошедшего, ни своими ожиданиями будущего.
Написал не так уж много на эту игру , и давайте посмотрим что мне понравилось , и не понравилось.
Порадовало: мощная атмосфера вопреки минималистской подаче;
великолепная музыка;
заигравшие новыми красками старые шаблоны;
сюжет интригует до конца.
Огорчило:многие «ружья» так и не выстрелили;
во флэшбеках не всегда понятно, что и с кем происходит.

**************************************************************************************************************************
Работу над вторым сезоном The Game Kitchen собираются начать уже летом — и они твердо намерены не сдавать завоеванные позиции. Хочется верить, что эту историю ждет достойное завершение. Она того стоит.

The Last Door (Season One) is a retro crowd-funded point and click adventure game with lovecraftian overtones. The protagonist, Jeremiah Devitt receives a letter from an old friend asking for his help and sets off on an adventure fraught with mystery and terror. 

Visuals in TLD are minimalistic to the point of being almost incomprehensible and I immediately had flashbacks of playing old Sierra text-parser adventure games. Thankfully, there is a point and click interface. Additionally, the graphical minimalism actually works in favor of the player since, with larger pixels, there is less of a “hunt” to find interactive objects. 

Puzzles range from generally easy to extremely easy with maybe one or two particular puzzles requiring the player to stop and think, so it’s best to go into TLD treating it as a story-based PnC game (a la telltale games) than as a serious adventure game.

The game is about 4-5 hours long and, for an average minimum sale price of $2, will give you just enough bang for your buck for a quick game to play over the course of a single evening. I’m looking forward to trying the sequel, once another sale rolls around.
